whyFunctions.speaker: Pixel
whyFunctions.text: Imagine coding 'enemy takes damage' 50 times... NO! Write it once as a function, call it 50 times!
whyFunctions.followUp: Functions = no repeating yourself = happy programmer = better games!

firstFunction.speaker: Pixel
firstFunction.text: Functions are defined with 'def' and called by name. Like creating a spell, then casting it!
firstFunction.codeExample:
# Define the function (create the spell)
def attack():
    print('Swinging sword!')
    print('Enemy takes 10 damage!')

# Call the function (cast the spell)
attack()
attack()  # Can use it multiple times!
firstFunction.followUp: See? Define once with 'def', then call it whenever you need!

parameters.speaker: Pixel
parameters.text: Yes! Parameters let functions accept inputs - like damage amounts or enemy names!
parameters.codeExample:
# Function with parameters
def attack(enemy_name, damage):
    print(f'Attacking {enemy_name}!')
    print(f'{enemy_name} takes {damage} damage!')

# Call with different values
attack('Goblin', 25)
attack('Dragon', 50)
attack('Slime', 10)
parameters.followUp: Parameters make functions flexible - one function, infinite possibilities!

defaultParams.speaker: Pixel
defaultParams.text: Default parameters give fallback values - perfect for optional settings!
defaultParams.codeExample:
# Default parameters
def heal(amount=50, show_effect=True):
    print(f'Healing {amount} HP!')
    if show_effect:
        print('âœ¨ Sparkles appear! âœ¨')

# Different ways to call
heal()           # Uses defaults: 50, True
heal(30)         # Custom amount: 30, True
heal(100, False) # Full custom: 100, False
heal(show_effect=False)  # Named parameter!
defaultParams.followUp: Defaults make functions user-friendly - they work even if you forget parameters!

returnValues.speaker: Pixel
returnValues.text: Functions can return values - like asking 'how much damage?' and getting an answer!
returnValues.codeExample:
# Function that returns a value
def calculate_damage(base, multiplier):
    total = base * multiplier
    return total

# Use the returned value
damage = calculate_damage(10, 3)
print(f'Total damage: {damage}')  # 30

# Return multiple values!
def get_stats():
    return 100, 50, 25  # health, mana, armor

hp, mp, armor = get_stats()
print(f'HP: {hp}, MP: {mp}, Armor: {armor}')
returnValues.followUp: Return sends values back to whoever called the function!

functionCalls.speaker: Pixel
functionCalls.text: Functions can call other functions - like combo attacks in fighting games!
functionCalls.followUp: Functions calling functions - that's how complex games are built!

scope.speaker: Pixel
scope.text: Variables inside functions are 'local' - they only exist in that function's bubble!
scope.codeExample:
player_gold = 100  # Global variable

def buy_item(cost):
    # Local variable - only exists here
    tax = cost * 0.1
    total = cost + tax
    
    global player_gold  # Access global variable
    if player_gold >= total:
        player_gold -= total
        return True
    return False

# Use it
if buy_item(50):
    print(f'Purchase complete! Gold left: {player_gold}')
else:
    print('Not enough gold!')
scope.followUp: Local variables = function's private stuff. Global = shared with everyone!

options.text: Show me a game system example!

completeExample.speaker: Pixel
completeExample.text: Let's build a complete combat system with functions!
completeExample.codeExample:
# Combat System
import random

def create_character(name, hp, attack):
    return {'name': name, 'hp': hp, 'attack': attack}

def attack_enemy(attacker, defender):
    damage = random.randint(1, attacker['attack'])
    defender['hp'] -= damage
    print(f"{attacker['name']} deals {damage} damage!")
    return damage

def is_alive(character):
    return character['hp'] > 0

def battle(player, enemy):
    print(f"Battle: {player['name']} vs {enemy['name']}!")
    
    while is_alive(player) and is_alive(enemy):
        attack_enemy(player, enemy)
        if is_alive(enemy):
            attack_enemy(enemy, player)
        print(f"HP - {player['name']}: {player['hp']}, {enemy['name']}: {enemy['hp']}")
    
    winner = player if is_alive(player) else enemy
    print(f"{winner['name']} wins!")

# Use the system
hero = create_character('Hero', 100, 20)
goblin = create_character('Goblin', 50, 15)
battle(hero, goblin)
completeExample.followUp: See how functions work together to create a complete system? That's modular programming!

lambdaIntro.speaker: Pixel
lambdaIntro.text: Bonus power-up: Lambda functions! Mini-functions for quick operations!
lambdaIntro.codeExample:
# Regular function
def double(x):
    return x * 2

# Lambda function - same thing!
double = lambda x: x * 2

# Great for sorting!
enemies = [
    {'name': 'Goblin', 'hp': 30},
    {'name': 'Orc', 'hp': 50},
    {'name': 'Slime', 'hp': 10}
]

# Sort by HP
enemies.sort(key=lambda e: e['hp'])
print('Weakest to strongest:')
for enemy in enemies:
    print(f"{enemy['name']}: {enemy['hp']} HP")
lambdaIntro.followUp: Lambdas are like instant spells - quick, one-line functions!
